factoid: Princess Mary is very nice and kind.
Princess Mary is pitied.
Princess Mary has no one.
The narrator does not need Princess Mary.
Princess Mary is in the narrator's way.
The narrator always was a savage.
The narrator is now even more savage.
The narrator likes being alone.
Father likes Princess Mary very much.
Father is gentle and kind to Princess Mary.
Father is gentle and kind to Michael Ivánovich.
Father has been a benefactor to Princess Mary.
Father has been a benefactor to Michael Ivánovich.
Father took Princess Mary when she was homeless after losing her own father.
Princess Mary is very good-natured.
Father likes Princess Mary's way of reading.
Princess Mary reads to Father in the evenings.
Princess Mary reads splendidly.
Prince Andrew asked Princess Mary about Father's character.
Princess Mary was first surprised and then aghast at Prince Andrew's question.
Princess Mary said "For me? For me?... Trying for me!..."
Prince Andrew said "Father always was rather harsh; and now I should think Father’s getting very trying."
Princess Mary said "You are good in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of intellectual pride."
Princess Mary said "and that’s a great sin."
Princess Mary said "How can one judge Father?"
Princess Mary said "But even if one might, what feeling except veneration could such a man as Father evoke?"
Princess Mary said "I am so contented and happy with Father."
Princess Mary said "I only wish you were all as happy as I am."
Princess Mary's brother shook his head incredulously.
Princess Mary said "The only thing that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth, Andrew... is Father's way of treating religious subjects."
Princess Mary said "I don’t understand how a man of Father's immense intellect can fail to see what is as clear as day, and can go so far astray."
Princess Mary said "That is the only thing that makes me unhappy."
Princess Mary said "But even in this I can see lately a shade of improvement."
Princess Mary said "Father's satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a monk Father received and had a long talk with."
Prince Andrew said "Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wasting your powder."
Princess Mary said "Ah! mon ami, I only pray, and hope that God will hear me."
Princess Mary said "I have a great favor to ask of you."
Princess Mary said "No—promise that you will not refuse! It will give you no trouble and is nothing unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise, Andrúsha!"
Princess Mary said "Even if it were a great deal of trouble..."
Prince Andrew answered "Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as you please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father’s father, our grandfather, wore it in all his wars."
Princess Mary said "So you promise?"
Prince Andrew said "Of course. What is it?"
Princess Mary said "Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will never take it off. Do you promise?"
Prince Andrew said "If it does not weigh a hundredweight and won’t break my neck... To please you..."
Prince Andrew added "I am glad; really, dear, I am very glad."
Princess Mary said "Against your will He will save and have mercy on you and bring you to Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace."
Princess Mary held up a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a gold setting on a finely wrought silver chain.
Princess Mary crossed herself.
Princess Mary kissed the icon.
Princess Mary handed the icon to Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary said "Please, Andrew, for my sake!"
Father's father is the grandfather of the narrator.
